WRITING.TEXT:
Yeah, pfft, big deal. Try Death Valley. Go to Libya, you baby.
Jesus Christ, people are allowed to have experiences and make comments even if they may not be the very most extreme example. The world isn't just a conversation of superlatives and everything else is pointless to every speak of.

Looks really interesting. I've always really loved movie poster art and get excited when a new book of an artist's work or a project like this comes along and spotlights it.
As big of a fan of his work as I am, this looks like it'll be better than the recent Drew Struzan documentary. As someone mainly working in digital art these days, I was soured on it somewhat because of the antiquated, quasi-offensive view they hold onto regarding digital illustrating, simply lumping absolutely everything done on a computer with the shittiest of generic floating head posters. Not everything done on a computer is garbage and not everything painted on canvas is a sacred work of art.
Anyway..sorry, that really stuck in my craw. I'm as excited about seeing the old masters getting some attention once again as I am about the coverage of the Mondo posters and the resurgence of cool poster art. I'm especially looking forward to seeing Jason Edmiston's work, he's amazing.

I think what makes Wilfred work independently, possibly better as I ruminate on it, is that there's much more fueling Ryan's hallucinations. The backstory with the cult and his parents and details of growing up is such a rewarding explanation for how Wilfred came to be, where there is nothing specific that conjures Tyler Durden out of the aether and his appearance and character is nothing beyond being "id".

I worked with these folks doing some video work a couple years ago, but it doesn't look like the project has gotten completely off the ground yet. The dream has not yet arrived.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLYc1KMdSrI
Yes, the thing that grabbed the most was the painterly look, they better not lose that.

I've always been fascinated by the Mothman since I grew up in West Virginia, that connection and that unlike Bigfoot or the Loch Ness Monster it seemed to be a singular event that had no solid answers, so it has a good mysterious legacy. I've not seen this special, I'll have to check it out.

That's not the final image. And we'll assume they meant a screengrab, not a painted interpretation. [Here's that](http://i.imgur.com/RZZ1dvB.png). and while I was at it, I couldn't help but grab a few more from the closing moments. It was a really well shot sequence full of good images.
http://imgur.com/a/QWTcZ
Right right, the AVYMGA.

I'd love to be able to use this album as a feed for the Muzei live wallpaper on Android. The quotes were always one of my favorite parts of each episode.
Edit: Duh...not that hard just to download the album and use "My Photos" as the feed with Muzei. These should be some fun backgrounds for a few weeks.

I've thought about this too. I guess it might depend on how exactly the "ending" criteria is defined, as some big moments kinda blend together and could only *maybe* be interpreted as endings. Here's what I'd identify at least as bullet points that contribute to the closure of the narrative.
- Learning about the cult from his mother - Meeting his father, learning more about what specifically fueled his psychosis - Jenna leaving with Drew - Kristen's new job - Seeing the truth about the basement - Choosing Wilfred
Not necessarily always. There are plenty of scenes with just the two of them, and they could be questioned.

This is something that's been sticking in my head too. I was very satisfied with the ending but I have to wonder how well a rewatch will go. I worry the show in general will, at best, turn into something rather depressing and awkward and at worse Ryan will become extremely psychotic and unrelatable and unsympathetic. Fight Club overall could be viewed as a shallow, ugly, fairly sinister story so its reveal can't really "harm" it in retrospect in that regard, but Wilfred always had a lot of warmth and light-heartedness which could be killed in a pretty significant way when we look back.

There's nothing dense about it. It's so clever that it's wasted space all day long.
In any case, it looks photoshopped to me anyway.
Yes, that would be the basis for the joke. They said FROM New Jersey, therefore unfamiliar with the whole process of fueling.
Would "a vague yet menacing government agency" fall into your less desirable single noun category?
It's so sad in light of the fact that before modern medicine no depressed person had ever committed suicide.
That's really interesting, I hope that idea is in the next movie.

But no where is there any sense of regret or concern about the, surely, thousands of people he's injured, killed or displaced. Only when he kills Zod is there any response, and when you've watched him, seemingly, nonchalantly destroying cities up to this point, that response falls pretty flat. I get that there would be, and needs to be, collateral damage with two superbeings fighting, but there were better ways to handle that while remembering Superman's characterization.
People make lots of things that you can buy.

I think for a lot of people it was the ridiculous, over the top destruction-porn that completely undermines the core of the Superman character. You knock such a crucial pillar out from under the character and it brings the whole project down and makes Snyder look (even more some would say after some misguided choices in Watchmen) like someone who glosses over or simply doesn't understand important characterizations for the sake of whiz bang visuals. Which then makes you question WB in their decision to approve his work and then hire him on again for an even higher rung on their movie universe ladder.
Marvel's movies can be flawed, but most wouldn't argue that their is a strong sense of direction and cohesion there and overall everyone involved has seemed to understand their respective properties.
[Bryan Cranston loves fire ant torture.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GrgRAGXpWLU t=21m10s)

Yeah, each book, a strange choice in my opinion, has a different artist...except the last which is also done by Michael Whelan. I wish he could've illustrated the whole series. I was pretty disappointed when I finished the audio book for books 4 and 6 and then sought out the illustrations online. Not my preferred style, much rather have the more representative style find in the others.
Ahh, okay, fair enough. I would read it as her recognizing the name, I'd expect her to be savvier and quicker than most and would catch it.
There's no way they would've used the name Cam if they didn't intend it to be Magnussen, there's a million other names they could have used.

Very cool! I'm with ya on anything worth doing is worth doing right, which is why tackling it alone would be tough for me right now. But if we could split the responsibilities up some, that could work out really well.

If you'd like some artistic help, shoot me a message. I'm actually working on another map right now, between that and my real, paying work I wouldn't have time to do the necessary Derry research now. If you were planning on doing that and taking notes and would like some assistance on the drafting part of things...it could be a fun project.
Not to step in on your project, it's just always fun to create a map like this and thought I'd offer any skills I had to help. If not wanted, I'll be excited to see what you come up with!
Something besides the two Best of discs? I probably should've been more specific, that I wish the *series* would get a release...DVD, iTunes, whatever.

God, I wish Trigger Happy TV would get some sort of official release. This is among a few shows I loved that juuuuust missed the edge of the era we're in now where basically everything gets a DVD release and aren't hugely popular enough to, it seems, garner interest from anyone to go back and do it.

Could I ask how old you are? The show was pretty ubiquitous throughout the 90s. The RLM guys are roughly my age, 31, and so for people who like to poke fun at and scrutinize bad movies to have avoided a show tailor made for them during their formative years...it's amazing.
Oh for sure, I think it's really curious that they weren't fans, but it's for the better now to be able to produce their show without those preconceived notions.

I'm not outraged, it was just a noticeable peculiarity. Personally, I know..a silly basis for any argument...nothing about what Spoony is or his connection to the movie, but I think there's a large difference in an internet celebrity, of which there are thousands these days, and a show that ran for ten years at a time when it was a unique giant in the world of spotlighting bad movies.
I see Tom Servo but I haven't found Crow yet, I'd assume he has to be in there, right? it's driving me crazy.
Interesting. That makes sense to avoid it these days, but it's mind-boggling that most of them would not have been drawn to it and obsessed when they were kids.

Like I said, it's one of the most mentioned/quoted episodes, and there's going to be a ton of overlap in the audiences. They don't necessarily *need* to, again, the best way to describe it for me was *distracting*, I just assumed they would have to bring it up. They rattle off directors and actors that are extremely obscure because they assume there is some familiarity with them for the audience because they enjoy bad movies, so to not mention a long-running, beloved show built around bad movies is just a bit odd. I was equally distracted for a long time by Amy Smart being in High Voltage, but thankfully they eventually mentioned that.

There's certainly no reason for them to refrain from doing it on their show as well, but it's sorta weird and almost distracting to see Space Mutiny featured with no mention of it being one of the most popular MST3K episodes.
Hmmm, I kind want to write this script now...hmmm.

Oh totally, continuity is something to be laughed and thrown to the wayside. I wouldn't be surprised if in a couple weeks it's a Christmas episode all about how Joe is worried how Santa is going to get through the dome.
I still feel overwhelmed and have things left undone at the end of most days, and without taking 20 minutes to wash my hands or 45 minutes to take a shower.
Want me never to watch a video? Put it on a site or format without volume controls.
"See you in another dome, brotha!" "Dome tell me what I can't do!" "We either learn to live together, or we dome alone." "Let me tell you something about domes, John. They are a fickle bitch."
Not according to Joe.

I'm just saying anyone taking about the finale right now is far from an impartial source and would be silly to use as a point of reassurance. Elijah Wood isn't going to say how disappointing it is or anything besides a shining endorsement.

That's really interesting. Inspired by digital artifacting? Touch of color is nice, I like how it extends beyond the apparent border, adds another layer to the "corruption effect".
It's everything pop culture. Probably in the last fifteen years or so, it's really blown up to cover everything.
I was shocked it was only a minute long, but it's only through season 3, so that explains some of it.

This doesn't necessarily account for all of the decline, but most shows like this would follow the same pattern. The first season is going to be the most accessible so it's likely to grab the most eyeballs and then as the show progresses, it's only natural for the wheat to be separated from the chaff, so to speak...the show continues to whittle away and get the audience that is more dedicated to stick with it and see through to the end. Not that the show is flawless and hasn't done things to send some of those committed viewers away, but I think most serialized/quasi-mystery shows would have a ratings graph likes this.
Yeah, I tried to look up the band and their website, at least the site linked from Lostpedia was dead. A bit tough to try to find songs and lyrics now.

I was actually just searching out some Celtic/Irish music on a random whim a couple days ago, this bundle came along at just the right time! Thanks for the link. And it looks like Weird Al's got a really good chance of making it.
It doesn't sound like the band Previously on Lost, I'm pretty familiar with all their songs. Could it be "The Others"? I don't know their stuff as well.

Some of you might be reading this without having watched the episode, and all I can say to you is, hold onto your pants because the revelationsHOLY SHIT THAT'S THE EPISODE TITLEof "Revelations" will blow your Jordaches clear off your butt and out the window and into a puddle of muck on the side of the road where a hobo will pick them up and wear them while it train hops across the Midwest. Prepare to get DOMED.
This is one of the best things written. Man, these write-ups are great.

I'm with you. Looking back, yeah they could've been trimmed from the show in the writer's room and no one in the universe would've cared, but for being forced to deal with the unfortunate situation as it was, "Expose" was really great.
Why do you say that? Looks just like him. It could be from pre/early production so he has longer hair and doesn't have the full look yet.
God, no kidding. I hated Steam the Christmas I got Half Life 2, forcing me to go through all this horseshit when I had the disc...it was a looooong night of downloading.
No, I would concede that. Under the Dome is in a special place of hilariously bad, where Dexter really only sunk to boring or unsatisfying because it showed so much promise early on.
Ahhh, that would explain it.

Personally, it's very close and it might even tip more onto "bad" as far as crummy seasons of Dexter. Characters become caricatures and unlikable. Uninspired main plots...how many times do we need to see Dexter become close in some capacity to someone only to realize he can never be close to someone. Dull, forced side plots that are done out of obligation and not because the supporting cast is so interesting. Boring serial-killer-of-the-season arcs. And probably worst overall, the show was too cowardly towards genuine change and upset, if it was trimmed by a couple seasons and didn't have to spin it's wheels and leave Dexter basically back to status quo at the end of the season, it's legacy could've been much stronger. There were great moments and good episodes in its latter half, but when you average and consider the seasons as a whole, the show was pretty lackluster after season 4.

Yeah, it could go bad in some cases, but my immediate thought isn't, "Shame on anyone who gets an elderly person a pet. Shaaaaame."
Yeah, looked air tight. Probably been in there for days.
Huh, two in Utah and neither is Salt Lake county, surprised me. I guess a natural resource situation.
Don't stop there, let's be thoroughly annoyingly pedantic..font is not just the size but the weight and style.
Really? I'd never heard it started out as a miniseries. That seems quite a task to change gears halfway through a season, from a finite series to something open ended.

God, this argument drives me nuts. There's a difference in giving into a fantastical premise and noticing and criticizing the filmmakers fucking up. Every movie gets harped on for committing continuity errors and logistical flubs like people have mentioned here. Being a sci-fi/supernautral movie never makes it immune to ANY complaints.

He didn't say anything about grammar mistakes, he was criticizing it from a songwriting angle. I agree with you oriss27, I had the exact thought about the crowbar line. I don't fancy myself a songwriter by any stretch, but I do have this nerve that gets tweaked when I hear lines like that that have too clunky of a flow or some weird peculiarity like that, totally agree that in this case dropping "stupid" would make it easier to sing the line syllabically and have a steadier flow.
I love the recent addition of Rick moving closer in the last frames.
Indeed, the dumb seasons fit perfectly in my window between Flashforward and Under the Dome.
Really, really well done!

Wow, I'm a big Weezer fan and was just thinking last week that it was surprising they somehow had escaped Weird Al until Beverly Hills, I'd never heard this bit of trivia before. Very cool to be able to hear it.
It's truly tragic. :( Think of all the Joseph Fiennes faces we missed out on.

There are those rare, wonderful shows that come along every few years that suck so good. Flashforward used to be fill that void for me, then Dexter did a good enough job until Under the Dome came along.

Even doing that, there's still been plenty of posts talking about [Amanda being back and the actors changing](/spoiler)...stuff I'd personally rather not know about beforehand and enjoyed as surprises.

I would chalk that up to music videos just not having the presence they once had. MTV is not thing it was in the 80s and 90s and the parodied songs aren't as strongly identified with the video in the public's mind as they once might have been. Personally, I don't know what any of the original music videos in the last two or three albums would've looked like. In the last decade, with YouTube, you've got live versions and TV appearances and fan made videos diluting the artist's output to the point that with a really popular song, a good percentage of the viewers might not know what the actual official music video is.
Last year they said something along the lines of "the reason for the dome is different." To what extent that means diverging from the book, who knows right now.
Yes, there are always exceptions, I know. But when a movie sits on a shelf for a year your first instinct isn't to think it was for any good reasons.
Yes, an exactly comparable situation.
Hopefully that's largely it. But it was done and they could've released it last Halloween.
I really liked the book so I've been excited, but I'm worried about why it's taken this long to release..typically not a good sign.

Sure, I suppose that's true. With only the peripheral connection, enjoying the reveal could work in both directions. Though watching the TV show first, one would probably be a bit more bewildered than doing it the other way around.
That's not 100% true. It's certainly not required viewing, but it wouldn't hurt to have seen the movie first.
I think we can put our differences aside...for science...you monster.
Wow, I always assumed it was just a photoshopped image, never saw the making-of photos, that's very neat.

I wouldn't quite go to "shitty", but I can only take so many dream fakeouts before I don't get caught up in them and become apathetic to resist being fooled. Still...chills when Wilfred took off the suit.
Road Rage was, but this is Hit and Run.
Very enjoyable. Not a huge, showy performance but a very impressive, subtle unique delivery for the multiple voices in the book.

Yeah, there's a short like you describe called The Lawnmower Man from the Night Shift collection. Some funny legal wrangling with the rights and wanting to stamp King's name on something led to the barely related feature film.
There's a cheap short film of the original story out there too, it's sorta fun.

I'd strongly disagree, I never felt any of it was frustrating, I enjoyed just being able to spend more time with the characters in this format. Just because the story possibly **could** be boiled down to feature film length doesn't mean it **should** anymore than a book should only exist as a Wikipedia summary because it can be stripped down to a few paragraphs. The smaller moments and nuances are what really make a show like this for me, a two hour film would probably lose a bunch of the side characters and the story and town wouldn't feel as fleshed out as it did on TV. Endless isn't always better of course, a show could certainly spin it's wheels and get dull. But in this case, I personally never felt like the show was annoyingly being padded.

The marketing angle seems really dumb. Lotta new people gonna be hooked by the title change and check out a third installment in a series? Fans of the first two movies gonna be turned off by "There and Back Again" and possibly skip the last movie?
I don't question that the marketing was part of the reasoning behind, but like a lot of decisions made on that basis, it's stupid.

The movie adaptations aren't masterpieces..though haven't seen the older one since high school...but I've always really enjoyed the book "A Separate Peace". Dead Poets Society was certainly inspired by it to a certain degree, it takes place in a New England prep school and covers some of the same themes of seizing the day and dealing with growing and learning and death. It's written from the perspective of an older man thinking back in his high school days and I still get a little punch in the gut when I think about how well the book captures the bittersweet nostalgia.
There was a movie made in 1972 and a Showtime movie back in the 2000s.
I really like the way they draw, I just wish the physical pen was a bit more comfortable to hold. The ridge for the cap seems noticeably sharp after a while.

This is a tough one for me to swallow. There are plenty of zealots out there willing to die for their "causes", but I think it's harder to believe you could have one that was so brilliant and unflappable..or I guess such a good performer if he isn't actually as brilliant as we've seen him act and react. It's one thing to be someone's mask in a more distanced way, like working from the safety of recorded messages or something. But I think it's another to be out in the real world, for all appearances untethered from the "real Moriarty" and having to think on your feet in situations with real danger.
Yeah, I guess it's great to have official confirmation but this is nothing too fantastic, it's exactly the estimate we'd had before. But with a Christmas special, so that's something nice.
I'm guessing Noah Hawley. I'm not too shocked to see Billy Bob Thornton being absent.
The long arm of the law.
Wow, I feel dumb, I'd always thought Jimmy Barrett was a real comedian and was about to mention him in the thread, but I've been wrong. I wonder who I've been confusing that name with.
Link?

Yeah, it's not a straight sci-fi/mystery show in the sense of necessitating answers, but they could've easily formatted it as a much simpler, absurd comedy and left out all the clues and hints to the greater mystery if they didn't have intentions of answering questions. If they back off too much now and don't follow through, it'll be disappointing.

WRITING.TITLE: I've been excited for the finale all week, so here's my drop in the fan art bucket.
My pub trivia team's name is "All Glory To The Hypnotoad", so I made a Hypnotoad mascot for our table.
